messages: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:42): does anyone know how accurate are Amazon's delivery estimates generally are? The site orignally said 7 to 10 days for products shipped to Norway, but now that it's despatched, they're telling me 19 days
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:43): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: They are usually made up by untrained armadillos
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:43): I didn't want to have to wait nearly 3 weeks :-(
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (16:43): their estimates for delivery to NZ are often pretty bad
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (16:43): they'll say 3 weeks and I get it in 8 days
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (16:43): so 'bad' in a good way
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:43): Or the opposite
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:44): I have had "it will be (small number of days) and it was actually (large number of days)"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:44): er, the second " was in quite the wrong place there
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (16:48): hey, can someone point me in the right direction, i have some lines rendered on canvas
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (16:48): and i want to be able to measure them
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (16:48): with the mouse ;
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (16:48): just wondered if anyonecould point me at some recommened reading>?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:52): d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80, in what unit do you want to measure them? Number of pixels? length in mm as rendered on the screen? Other?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:53): in any case, I think the basic concept of doing that is to find the position of line's end points, and then use a bit of trig to calculate the length
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:56): or, actually, a^2 = b^2 + c^2 should be enough to calculate the length, where b and c are abs(x1-x2) and abs(y1-y2)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:57): (You don't need abs)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:58): yeah, I realised that after I wrote it cause they're squared. But whatever
b91adcb9dadbcdd2609eef5ff978162c (16:58): If I use HTML5 can I use <script> tags or will I still need to include the text/javascript for the time being?
b91adcb9dadbcdd2609eef5ff978162c (16:58): looking to support IE7 on up
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:59): b91adcb9dadbcdd2609eef5ff978162c: You mean writing <script> instead of <script type="text/javascript">?
b91adcb9dadbcdd2609eef5ff978162c (16:59): correct
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:59): That works and has always worked and will always work
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:59): so there's no compatibility problem
b91adcb9dadbcdd2609eef5ff978162c (16:59): ah ok cool, but wasn't it invalid with html4?
b91adcb9dadbcdd2609eef5ff978162c (16:59): ok awesome, thanks
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:59): b91adcb9dadbcdd2609eef5ff978162c: It may have been
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:59): d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80, ok, then that's really simple
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:00): b91adcb9dadbcdd2609eef5ff978162c: but that's independent of what browsers support (and have to support, since lots of people already write <script>)
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:00): with xy coords of the mouse?
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:00): any way to lock on corners/endpoints?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:00): do you mean, when the user clicks a point on the canvas, how do you get those co-ordinates?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:01): or do you want to snap to the nearest end-point of an existing line?
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:01): well mouse XY will do i suppose, but it would be great ifi could snap to existing endpoints
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:02): do you have a collection with all the line end point co-ordinates, that you can search through?
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:03): a collection?
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:03): errm
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:04): well i guess i could make one
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:04): like stick all the endpoints in an array or something

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:05): so then when you capture the mouse event, you get the x,y coords from that event object, adjusting for the element's position (can't remember the exact code for this off hand)
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:06): ok that doesnt sound too hard
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:06): then when you have those coords, you have to search through the array to find the nearest point.
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:06): heh CAD in browser
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:06): that requires some math that I'm not personally familiar with, but you should be able to find it through a web search
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:06): im pretty good with the maths
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:07): but the code escapes me sometimes!
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:07): it's probably something simple like finding the lowest values of (mouseX - pointX) and (mouseY - pointY), for each point
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:07): It's just the same maths as before
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:07): oh, yeah, find the shortest hypotenuse will do it
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:07): well I wouldnt have thourght of storing all of the end points, so thats good
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:08): this way, i can scale the canvas down, and the measuring will still work
d7304e43ecdabb4efa0636d51408ca80 (17:11): thanks alot guys
